instructions.title: Welcome to The Career Compass Assessment!
instructions.content:
This assessment will help you discover your interests, strengths, and growth areas.
By understanding these key aspects of yourself, you'll begin the journey of finding your True North — the direction that aligns with your unique potential and purpose.
tips: There are no right or wrong answers — be honest
Use Next and Back buttons to navigate
You can't move forward without answering every question on the page

categories.title: Realistic (Doers)
questions: I like working with my hands to build or fix things
I am interested in how machines or tools work
I enjoy being outdoors and active
I like practical tasks more than reading or writing
I enjoy sports or physical activities
I like working with animals or plants

categories.title: Investigative (Thinkers)
questions: I like solving puzzles or figuring out how things work
I enjoy doing research or learning about new topics
I like science experiments
I enjoy finding solutions to problems
I am curious about how things are made
I like working with numbers and data

categories.title: Artistic (Creators)
questions: I enjoy drawing, painting, or designing things
I like writing stories, poems, or songs
I enjoy music, acting, or dance
I like creating new ideas or trying new ways of doing things
I enjoy decorating or making things look attractive
I like expressing myself in creative ways

categories.title: Social (Helpers)
questions: I enjoy helping people with their problems
I like working in teams or groups
I enjoy teaching or explaining things to others
I like making people feel welcome and included
I enjoy listening to people's stories
I like doing things that make a difference in people's lives

categories.title: Enterprising (Persuaders)
questions: I enjoy leading group projects

categories.title: Conventional (Organisers)
questions: I enjoy following a clear plan or set of instructions
I like keeping things neat and organised
I enjoy working with numbers, charts, or spreadsheets
I like following rules and making sure others do too
I enjoy filing, sorting, or organising information
I like doing tasks step-by-step in the right order

categories.title: Growth
questions: Even once I am in my career, I want to learn new things.
Work that is challenging and pushes me to grow every day, excites me.
Career progression and promotion opportunities are important to me.

categories.title: Security
questions: I want a job that provides a steady and predictable income every month.
I prefer a predictable career path with clear expectations and not a career that is unpredictable.
Earning a high income is important to me.

categories.title: Flexibility
questions: I want to choose where and when I work.
I value variety in my tasks and projects.
Work–life balance is a high priority for me.

categories.title: Recognition
questions: It's important to me that my work is recognised by others.
I enjoy roles where I can take leadership or be seen as an expert.
I'm motivated by achievements and awards.

categories.title: Innovation
questions: I enjoy finding new ways to solve problems.
I want to work in a fast-changing, creative environment.
I value freedom to experiment and test new ideas.

sections.title: Section A: Career Clusters (Interests)
sections.description:
In the assessment, you were given 6 questions each on 6 different categories. These categories are the 6 different career clusters as defined by Dr John Holland.
Why did we ask you this? To begin to narrow down your career choices based on your natural personality traits.
Based on the results of the assessment, your dominant/preferred career clusters are:
sections.guidance:
What you should do: Start researching jobs/careers fields within your dominant/preferred career clusters.
People with inconsistent patterns may find it beneficial to explore careers in specialized, interdisciplinary, or unique fields that align with their diverse traits.

sections.title: Section B: Career Drivers
sections.description:
In the assessment, you were given 3 questions each on 5 different categories. These categories are the 5 main career drivers/motivators (which are currently age appropriate for you – this will change as you age). A career driver/motivator is the thing that pushes you forward and gives you energy in your future career. It's what matters most to you when you think about work.
Why did we ask you this? To begin to align important traits to your dominant/preferred career clusters.
Based on the results of the assessment, your career drivers scored accordingly:
sections.guidance: What you should do: Start narrowing down your dominant/preferred clusters (and subsequent career choices), based on your Top 3 career drivers.

sections.title: Section C: Strengths and Skills
sections.description:
In the assessment, you were asked to evaluate yourself on 27 different strengths and skills. These can be further categorized into 9 strength clusters. These skills have been identified through research to be current high demand skills within the workplace. In line with helping you find your 'True North', it is important then to analyze your current strengths within these skills.
Why did we ask you this? To begin to identify your strengths and identify how these strengths are aligned to your dominant/preferred career cluster.
Based on the results of the assessment, your strengths clusters ranked as below:
sections.guidance:
What you should do:
1. Look to see how relevant your top 3 strengths are to your dominant/preferred career cluster
2. Look to see how relevant your lowest scoring 3 strengths are to your dominant/preferred career cluster.
3. Find ways to improve your lowest scoring 3 strengths. Feel free to check our list of training courses and workshops.

sections.title: Section D: Growth Areas
sections.description:
In the assessment, you were asked to evaluate yourself on 15 workplace readiness behaviors. These can be further categorized into 6 growth areas. These behaviors have been identified through research to be current high demand skills within the workplace. In line with helping you find your 'True North', it is important to know and work on, what your growth areas may be, as these behaviors are necessary for you to be successful in your chosen field.
Why did we ask you this? To begin to identify your growth areas and understand how these are aligned to your dominant/preferred career cluster.
Note: The statements in this section are worded negatively, so a higher score indicates a greater need for growth in that area.
Based on the results of the assessment, your growth areas ranked as below (1-3 being highest growth areas):
sections.guidance:
What you should do:
1. Look to see how relevant your highest scoring growth areas are to your dominant/preferred career cluster
2. Find ways to improve your 3 highest growth areas. Feel free to check our list of training courses and workshops.
